title: Alberto Jara Saguier
text:
Alberto Isidoro Jara Saguier (born 30 September 1943) is a former <a href="association%20football">football</a> <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> and coach. Alberto is one of the seven <a href="Jara%20Saguier%20%28disambiguation%29">Jara Saguier</a> brothers that played professional football in Paraguay.
Career.
As player.
Born in <a href="Asunci%C3%B3n">Asunción</a>, Paraguay, Jara Saguier started his career in the youth divisions of his hometown club <a href="Rubio%20%C3%91%C3%BA">Rubio Ñú</a> and eventually made the first team, helping the club win the <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20Paraguay">second division tournament</a> in 1963. He was then transferred to <a href="France">French</a> club <a href="Red%20Star%20Saint-Ouen">Red Star Saint-Ouen</a> in 1966, and the following year signed for <a href="Real%20Mallorca">Real Mallorca</a> of Spain before returning to Paraguay to play for <a href="Olimpia%20Asunci%C3%B3n">Olimpia Asunción</a> (1969), <a href="Club%20Libertad">Libertad</a> (1970) and <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20River%20Plate%20%28Asunci%C3%B3n%29">River Plate de Asunción</a> (1971).
At the national team level, Alberto Jara Saguier was part of the <a href="Paraguay%20national%20football%20team">Paraguay squad</a> that competed in the qualifiers for the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1966 FIFA World Cup</a>, which Paraguay failed to qualify.
As coach.
Alberto Jara Saguier managed the youth divisions of Olimpia, <a href="Cerro%20Porte%C3%B1o">Cerro Porteño</a>, <a href="General%20Caballero%20ZC">General Caballero ZC</a> and other small teams in the <a href="Ciudad%20del%20Este">Ciudad del Este</a> area. He managed the first team of clubs like <a href="Sportivo%20Ite%C3%B1o">Sportivo Iteño</a>, Sportivo Isla Pucú, Sportivo Coronel Oviedo, Minga Guazú, Deportivo Boquerón and Club Atletico 3 de Febrero
